channel.title: RSS Aggregator Feed

item.title: Apple AI chief steps down amid Siri struggles
item.description: Apple AI chief John Giannandrea is stepping down from his position, according to an announcement on Monday. The change comes as Apple struggles to get the launch of its AI-powered Siri back on track after delaying its launch earlier this year. Now, Apple is appointing Amar Subramanya as its vice president of AI. Subramanya spent […]

item.description: Technics' excellent EAH-AZ100 simply can't be bettered when it comes to audio quality, and at this all-new, even lower price (better than Black Friday), there's no better time if it's got to be the best…

item.title: The hidden cost of cloud centralization
item.description: Architect for failure and you’ll build resilience into your system. When AWS’s US-East-1 region went dark in late October, followed just a week later by a Microsoft Azure outage, it was yet another stark reminder that even the world’s biggest cloud vendors are not immune to failures. A simple DNS failure in AWS’s Route 53 rippled outward, knocking out applications, disrupting database services, and reminding us how dependent our tech infrastructure has become on a handful of cloud regions. With “an inadvertent tenant configuration change,” the Azure outage further highlighted the instability ...

item.title: Winter Kicks Off With Back-to-Back Arctic Blasts and a Potential Bomb Cyclone
item.description: Frigid temps and heavy snow gripped much of the U.S. on December 1, the first day of meteorological winter. It looks like these bitter conditions are here to stay.

item.title: Voici le PC « parfait » pour Linux selon son créateur
item.description: Linus Sebastian (LTT) a enfin construit un PC pour Linus Torvalds, le père de Linux. Mais oubliez les LED RGB et les boucles de watercooling complexes. La machine du créateur de Git est une leçon de pragmatisme brut qui risque de vexer pas mal de "gamers".

item.title: Astronomers Have Found 6,000 Exoplanets—but This Could Be the First Known Exomoon
item.description: After decades of searching, astronomers may have finally stumbled upon the first moon known to exist beyond our solar system—and it's an absolute giant.

item.title: Netflix Won't Let You Cast Shows From Your Phone to Most TVs Anymore
item.description: The streaming giant quietly removed the feature that lets you control content on your TV screen using a mobile device. The company says the feature was not widely used.

I know they have a built-in heart rate tracker, improved bass performance, and that they include a set of extra small silicone ear tips — totaling a whopping five sizing options in […]

item.title: What to know about this year’s White House holiday decorations
item.description: Planning for the holidays starts months in advance, and the White House said Melania Trump chose every detail of the decor. Melania Trump on Monday unveiled the holiday decorations for her family’s first Christmas back at the White House and her theme is “Home Is Where the Heart Is.”

item.title: Nvidia announces new open AI models and tools for autonomous driving research
item.description: Nvidia continues its push into physical AI with the release of a new reasoning world model and other tools for physical AI.

item.title: 92% of millennials use dating apps while at work
item.description: Recent survey data also shows that 74% of Gen Z do the same. The office is now officially the second most popular spot for swiping on dating apps, after home. That’s according to the latest survey from dating app Hily, as 74% of Gen Z and 92% of millennial daters admit to swiping on dating apps while at work.

item.title: There’s a New ‘Sonic’ Spin-Off Movie on the Way
item.description: A mysterious new 'Sonic' movie is joining the live-action 'TMNT' film in 2028—and we've got high hopes it's all about Shadow.

item.title: Starbucks to pay more than $38 million to NYC workers over labor violations
item.description: Most of the affected employees at Starbucks who held hourly positions will receive $50 for each week worked from July 2021 through July 2024. Starbucks will pay about $35 million to more than 15,000 New York City workers to settle claims it denied them stable schedules and arbitrarily cut their hours, city officials announced Monday.
